content: The Act titled "Enhanced Incentives for Charitable Giving Act of 1999" allows charitable contributions to certain low-income schools to be made in the next taxable year. The Act allows qualified low-income school contributions to be deemed made on the last day of the preceding taxable year if made before the tax return deadline. The Act allows qualified low-income school contributions to be deemed made on the last day of the preceding taxable year if made before the tax return deadline. A qualified low-income school contribution is a charitable donation to an educational organization that primarily serves students eligible for free or reduced-cost lunches. The amendment made by this section under the National School Lunch Act applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. SEC. 3 allows a deduction for charitable contributions to individuals who do not itemize deductions. Section 170 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow a direct charitable deduction for individuals who do not itemize their deductions. The deduction is equal to the lesser of the amount allowable under subsection (a) or $50 ($100 for joint returns). Subsection (b) of section 63 is also amended to accommodate this change. The amendment allows for a direct charitable deduction for individuals who do not itemize their deductions under section 170 of the Internal Revenue Code. This deduction is defined as a portion of the amount allowable under section 170(a) taken as a direct charitable deduction for the taxable year under section 170(m). Additionally, there are conforming amendments made to section 63 of the Code. The amendments made by this section include adding new language and a direct charitable deduction for individuals who do not itemize their deductions. Effective Date: applicable to taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. SEC. 4. INCREASE IN LIMIT ON CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS AS PERCENTAGE OF AGI. SEC. 5. LIMITED EXCEPTION TO EXCESS BUSINESS HOLDINGS RULE. In General, individual and corporate limits for charitable contributions are increased, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new rule for private foundations regarding ownership of voting stock in a publicly traded corporation. The foundation and disqualified persons must not collectively own more than 49 percent of the voting stock and 49 percent in value of all outstanding shares of all classes of stock in the business enterprise. The new rule for private foundations states that if the foundation and disqualified persons collectively own stock with readily available market quotations on an established securities market, and certain requirements are met, then the ownership limit is increased to 49 percent from 20 percent. The new rule for private foundations increases the ownership limit to 49 percent if the foundation and disqualified persons collectively own stock with readily available market quotations on an established securities market. Disqualified persons must not engage in self-dealing with the corporation. The new rule for private foundations allows ownership of voting stock up to 49 percent if the foundation and disqualified persons collectively own stock with market quotations. A certification signed by an audit committee of the Board of Directors is required for compliance. A certification signed by an audit committee of the Board of Directors is required for compliance, ensuring that no disqualified person has received compensation or engaged in self-dealing with the corporation. The new rule for private foundations allows ownership of voting stock up to 49 percent if the foundation and disqualified persons collectively own stock with market quotations. Disqualified persons receiving compensation or engaging in self-dealing with the corporation can be disregarded if corrected by the due date for the filing of the annual return. The amendment made by this section applies to foundations established by bequest of decedents dying after December 31, 1999.
